author: chfast
content: We finally reached the point we can implement the MSM via BLST and it has definitely linear complexity. So the EIP-2537 gas pricing has no sense in this context.

author: rjected
content: why does it make no sense? Linear complexity w.r.t what?

author: chfast
content: w.r.t. to the number of inputs. The spec says a sub-linear complexity is expected therefore there is gas discount.

author: rjected
content: I don't read anything in EIP-2537 referencing sublinear complexity being expected, just that compared to naive MSM, pippenger is better, hence the discount?

author: rjected
content: or, does the runtime just not match the gas pricing based on number of inputs?

author: chfast
content: I'm getting exactly the same cost per input no matter how many inputs. I.e. the cost is `num_inputs * C`. And BLST is using the pippenger algorithm or at least they claim they do.

author: rjected
content: hmm, I see, will try to replicate
